column10: Solvent and temperature effects on the reduction and amination reactions of electrophiles by lithium dialkylaminoborohydrides.
column11: The influence of temperature and solvent effects on the reduction and amination mechanisms of iodomethane by lithium N,N-diisopropylaminoborohydride (iPr-LAB) was examined in varying concentrations of THF and dioxane. The reactions of benzyl chloride and trimethylsilyl chloride with iPr-LAB in THF were also studied. The amination of iodomethane is favored over reduction at low and room temperatures in pure THF and with increasing the amount of dioxane in THF. At higher temperatures, the reduction reaction a
column13: Lubov Pasumansky, Christopher J Collins, Lawrence M Pratt, Ngân Van Nguyên, B Ramachandran, Bakthan Singaram
column14: Department of Chemistry, University of California Santa Cruz, 1156 High Street, Santa Cruz, California, USA.

column10: Tracheal epithelial cells in vitro as a model to study genotoxicity of airborne particulates.
column11: The major target site of airborne particulates is the tracheobronchial epithelium of the respiratory tract. It is also the origin of the most common cancer in man, bronchogenic carcinoma. Rodent tracheal epithelial cells in culture can be used to study the genotoxic activity of airborne particulates leading to mutation and cancer. Airborne particulates were collected in the heavily industrialized Rhine-Ruhr region using a high volume sampler HVS 150 (Ströhlein Instruments) equipped with glass fibre filters.
column12: Toxicology in vitro : an international journal published in association with BIBRA
column14: Medical Institute of Environmental Hygiene at the Heinrich-Heine-University, Gurlittstrasse 53, D-40223 Düsseldorf, Germany.

column10: Highly electrophilic organometallics for carbocationic polymerizations: from anion engineering to new polymer materials.
column11: Ion-ion interactions are a crucial but often overlooked aspect of many polymerization reactions. The precise nature of cation-anion binding is as yet poorly understood, and little is known of the extent of ionic interactions in the typically nonaqueous, low-polarity reaction media of most polymerizations. Nevertheless, adequate control of cation-anion interactions can greatly enhance the productivity and efficiency of chemical processes and can provide low-energy alternatives to current methods.
